text.b: Upper Estimation Boundary for Absolute Maximum

text.i: National Technical University of Ukraine “Kyiv Polytechnic Institute” (NTUU KPI), Kyiv, Ukraine

page.text: Abstract—Analysis of optimal algorithms for processing signals with prior ambiguity with respect to
their parameters that deals with absolute maximum distribution of Markovian process is conducted. Since
real algorithms are discrete, during analysis we have to deal with representation of a random process by
Markovian sequences. This introduces error into probability calculations, the upper boundary of which is
determined for solving some applied problems of statistical radio engineering.
Let’s consider a problem of analyzing a radio engineering system connected to Fokker–Planck–
Kolmogorov equation for conditional probability density of transition

for sequences from (2). Such problem arouses during processing of real signals in algorithm that use digital
special calculators. For example, from theory of optimal signal discovery in condition of prior ambiguity
with respect to its parameters a maximum-likelihood algorithm of signal processing is known that allows
extracting rectangular pulses with unknown duration on the background of receiver’s intrinsic noise [2].

The necessity of finding (9) was left outside the specialists’ viewpoint. After publication of papers [2, 3]
only questions of correspondence of the processing algorithm (Fig. 1) to the asymptotically optimal one
remained open, because in the papers synthesis results for discontinuous signals were questioned. Obviously
in this situation there was no time for solving the problem of practical implementation of algorithm (Fig. 1)
and error analysis (9), though in later publications solution of the synthesis problem for pulses of arbitrary
shape lead to continuous processing algorithm [4].
In reality this algorithm will not allow escaping sampling, because knowledge of instant when pulse
arrives to receiver’s input is needed for its operation, while in the majority of cases this time instant is
unknown. For practical implementation of algorithm [4] after sampling the integration procedure will need
to be started with each new sample using, in fact, the same multichannel processing.
Prior ambiguity with respect to the time of arrival could be overcome by substituting correlation
processing in algorithm (Fig. 1) with the corresponding filtering one. However practical implementation of
filtering signal processing is connected with its sampling, so there is no chance to escape multichannel
processing (discrete character with respect to signal’s spectrum bandwidth).
Let’s find obvious laws of calculating AMD errors that do not require strict mathematical derivations and
are connected with a transition from continuous processing algorithm to the discrete one. AMD of
continuous process will always be less than AMD of the corresponding discrete sequence, because for any
(Fig. 2) there is probability of the process exceeding threshold h in gaps between samples t
. Hence (9) is positive and is an absolute error in AMD calculations for a continuous process. It’s obvious

UPPER ESTIMATION BOUNDARY FOR ABSOLUTE MAXIMUM DISTRIBUTION
Let’s compare (10) with results of simulating discovery of stationary Markovian process using rule (5) in
MATLAB and Excel software. During simulation the white noise generator implemented using the Randn
function in MATLAB software generated WGN samples, while data arrays were processed in Excel
allowing for full control at all stages of calculations. For modeling of stationary Markovian process with the

As we see the experimental data represented for the discrete processing algorithm is always greater than
the calculated values of continuous algorithm. Even double scaling of probability representation (refer to
Fig. 3 with respect to Fig. 4) differences between probabilities for continuous process and modeling results
improve insignificantly. This is observed due to unlimited spectrum of stationary Markovian process.
, there is always a difference between probabilities that absolute maximum lies in the
negative half-plane for continuous and discrete algorithms.
